stories.alt_intro: When is a spoiler not a spoiler?
stories.body:
Kristin shot J.R.

Newhart was all a dream.

And that book the Kanamits are toting around on The Twilight Zone? It's a cookbook!

I come to reveal spoilers, not to hide them.

Modern television viewing, which allows us to watch nearly any show ever made pretty much whenever we wish, has come upon us so quickly that social convention is still catching up.

The critical question still to be settled among polite society: Where does discussion end and spoiling begin?

Lately, it seems that the pendulum has swung to the favour of people who feel they should be able to approach a series unsullied, castigating those who might – however innocently – dare to try to discuss a show they are still watching, or even thinking about watching.

Who hasn't tried to analyze the latest episode of Game of Thrones with the office fan club only to be shooed away by a co-worker who isn't caught up? Or been approached by a friend who has "finally watched House of Cards" only to be scolded for revealing a plot point that comes after Episode 1?

A colleague recently was castigated by a reader for writing about Emily Kinney and "spoiling" that her character had died on The Walking Dead – seven months earlier.

I say it is time for the pendulum to swing back.

It is time to free the people who watch television to talk about their shows and for those who lag behind to accept that spoiling simply is a risk of a leisurely viewing pace.

Do I need to declare a spoiler alert before writing that the New England Patriots won the last Super Bowl because someone might still have an unwatched copy on their DVR?

Of course not. So why do some viewers believe they must be extended the "courtesy" of universal silence by the rest of the world when it comes to fictional television?

Naturally, there are limits. I believe people can reasonably ask those around them for 48 hours of spoiler-free space after a new episode airs. For series from online sites like Netflix that arrive all at once, a month after the release date is an acceptable cushion, especially for the later episodes.

On the other hand, it is up to the procrastinators to steer clear of social media. Those spoiled by reading their Twitter feeds can only blame themselves.

There are certain elements we have an obligation to be circumspect about, for a few years at least. Plot twists that significantly affect the path of the story should not be blared out in mixed company. The solutions to murder mysteries should be protected.

Still, all this concern about spoilers is largely misplaced. A good television series is more than a plot; our enjoyment comes from how the plot is conveyed: what the characters are like, how the story changes them, how our emotions are affected, how the themes of the story illuminate our own lives.

Does knowing that Miss Bennet marries Mr. Darcy make us like Pride & Prejudice any less? Were you able to watch The Empire Strikes Back a second time knowing that Darth Vader was Luke's father? I'm guessing you know how Janet Leigh's shower turns out in Psycho even if you haven't seen the movie. That doesn't make it any less great of a film.

And so it should be with a television series. Learning of an important plot twist ahead of watching a show doesn't ruin anything. It removes the element of surprise from a very small moment of a long experience.

A 2011 study from U.C. San Diego even concluded that spoilers increased readers' enjoyment of literature.

So let's ease up on the demand to be spoiler-free. If you are late to a series, accept that you might learn a plot point or two in advance. It might make things better.

SPEAK FREELY

Here are 10 "spoilers" it is OK to discuss in public without warning. Listed in reverse chronological order:

Dr. McDreamy gets bad medical care on Grey's Anatomy. Let's see: Actor feuds with producers and talks extensively about his desire to leave a show. How did we think this would turn out?

Walter White dies at the end of Breaking Bad. And Hamlet dies at the end of Hamlet. It's what happens at the conclusion of a tragedy. What is important is how Walt dies and what his death means.

The girls of Orphan Black are clones. Yes, it is an important reveal in Season 1. Then again, if you didn't figure that out weeks before the reveal, then this show is over your head.

Matthew Crawley of Downton Abbey is a bad driver. The death of Dan Stevens' character was one of the worst-kept secrets in television history. Stevens quit the series to make movies in America. We all knew he was going to die, but no one could have predicted the artless way his demise was worked into the story.

Eddard Stark gets executed on Game of Thrones. The entire show rests on Eddard being killed at the end of Season 1 and his heirs scattered. It's what Game of Thrones is about. "Spoiling" this is like spoiling that Star Trek takes place in the future.

There are no answers to Lost. Before anyone invests 100 hours or so in watching Lost, they should be aware that the many riddles posed in the first six seasons will not be answered in the seventh. What do 4, 8, 15, 16, 23, 42 signify? How did the island lure the castaways? Why was Walt so important? You will never find out.

The Sopranos cuts to black. It is difficult to be alive in the 21st century and not be aware of the final image of HBO's groundbreaking series. Besides, knowing this tells you absolutely nothing about the 86 episodes that preceded it.

Carrie marries Big in Sex and the City. This was such an unsatisfying and illogical ending to an otherwise fun series that all prospective viewers should be warned in advance to avoid TV breakage.

No. 6 is No. 1 in The Prisoner. This psychedelic '60s relic was hard to follow, but if you didn't figure the answer to "Who is No. 1?" by Episode 2, you were doing too many drugs. The real mystery – one still up for discussion – is not who is No. 1, but why is he No. 1? Plus, the reveal happened nearly 50 years ago.

Series based on history are fair game. I've got some bad news: Anne Boleyn gets beheaded in Wolf Hall and The Tudors. Thomas Cromwell, too. Julius Caesar's friends stab him to death in Rome.

KEEP QUIET

Here are five spoilers you probably should still keep the lid on:

The rest of those Game of Thrones deaths. This show kills of regular characters with alarming regularity, and rarely with warning. Best to let the uninitiated go wander as unspoiled as possible – although there has been so much talk about the "red wedding" that most will figure that one out.

The identity of A. The whole point of Pretty Little Liars is discovering just who A is. But it's OK to tell prospective viewers that the answer keeps changing and you're not really sure the writers even know.

The end of Season 2 of Homeland. This is the kind of twist that is both a complete surprise and yet intrinsic to what happens afterward. Let the newbies enjoy it.

What happens between Dexter Morgan and the Trinity Killer. The climax of the fourth season of Dexter is perfectly shocking and shockingly perfect.

Who killed Laura Palmer. Yes, Twin Peaks is nearly 25 years old. But just as in Pretty Little Liars, this mystery is the cornerstone of the entire series – and the information might be important to the upcoming remake/sequel.

TNS

stories.alt_headline: Minions Happy Meal toy swears at kids
stories.alt_intro: McDonalds Happy Meal toy seemingly asks kids "what the f....?"
stories.body:
American parents are outraged with a Minions Happy Meal toy which seemingly swears at children.

Some of the McDonalds' figurines appear to say a garbled version of: "well I'll be damned," and "what the f...?"

'Minions' are the stars of the new animated blockbuster Minions, spun off from their original role in the Despicable Me series. The apparently genderless characters have become something of an uber-meme online, adorning affirmative Facebook posts the world over.

Several parents complained, some uploading videos of the offending specimens. 

Uploader Paul B was happy that his daughter took no interest in the toy. He first heard the cussing when picking it up after her, but wasn't sure until his wife said she heard the same thing.

"A McDonalds toy? I mean seriously?"

McDonalds claims the toys aren't swearing at all.

"Minions speak ' Minionese ,' which is a random combination of languages and nonsense words and sounds," their statement explains. "Any perceived similarities to words within the English language are purely coincidental."

In other words, a random string of human voice sounds has accidentally produced the offending statements. Of course, that's how random combinations work: a million monkeys on a million typewriters will produce the work of Shakespeare; a million word sounds garbled together on a million plastic toys will produce a few swear words.

Head to our Facebook page for more from Stuff Entertainment

stories.alt_headline: Man jumps on stage to charge iPhone
stories.alt_intro: The play was about to start - but Nick Silvestri really, really needed to charge his dying iPhone.
stories.body:
It's not bad enough people's ringing smartphones are interrupting live theatre - now audience members are even disrupting performances to charge their smartphones, too.

In a move that needs to be seen to be believed - but thankfully, there's video, this being 2015 - a US college student jumped onto the stage of a Broadway play in New York just as it was about to start to charge his iPhone 6.

"The crew had to stop the precook music, remove the cellphone , and make an announcement as to why you can't do that," audience member Chris York wrote on Facebook, according to Playbill.com.

"Truly. I am a quiet and reserved person and I took great joy in loudly heckling the idiot when he returned to take his phone back. Moron."

It wasn't even a working outlet — just a nonfunctional prop for the play.

As video of the audacious July 2 deed at the Booth Theatre went viral, 19-year-old Nick Silvestri of Seaford, Long Island, confessed that he was the one pictured.

It wasn't a joke or a dare, the lacrosse-playing community college student told Playbill.com - he just really needed to charge his iPhone 6. It was down to 5 per cent juice after a busy day in the big city with his friends and some cousins from California.

"Girls were calling all day," he said. "What would you do?"

Earlier Silvestri had tried to plug it into the USB port of a big-screen TV at a restaurant lounge while he dined, but was yelled at by the manager.

He was seated in the orchestra section when he spotted the prop outlet "and ran for it".

"That was the only outlet I saw, so I thought, 'Why not?' I was thinking that they were probably going to plug something in there on the set, and I figured it wouldn't be a big deal if my phone was up there too."

FROM THE ARCHIVES: Cellphone stops Hugh Jackman play

But members of the audience shouted and several security guards came running, Silvestri told Playbill.

"So I hopped off the stage. They were pretty mad. They said, 'What were you thinking?' I said, 'Hey, buddy, what's the problem?'"

He then asked the guards if he jump back on the stage and get his phone.

"They said, ' Are you crazy?" and got it for him.

According to Broadwayadjacent , Silvestri then asked, "Well, where can I charge it?"

The teenager was never able to charge it that night - but the theatre did let him stay after his mother profusely apologised.

The drama delayed the play's opening by about five minutes and led to some cast members tweeting about it.

A guy jumped on the stage and plugged his phone into the fake outlet on our set just before we started. @HandtoGodBway #fullmoon or #idiot ?
    — Sarah Stiles (@Lulubellestiles) July 3, 2015
        Dear general audience, an electrical socket that's a part of the set of the play is NOT for you to charge your iPhone.....just an FYI.....

    — Marc Kudisch (@MarcKuds) July 4, 2015
        But designer Beowulf Boritt, who designed the hyper-realistic church basement set for the play about a demonic hand puppet, is taking it as a compliment of sorts.

"It's not the easiest thing to go climb on stage. It takes a concerted effort—and I do it all the time," Boritt told Vanity Fair.

"It's certainly the first time anyone has gone onto one of my sets and tried to use it as a real space."

"Does this give me a new standard? It'll keep me from ever putting a toilet on stage."

LECTURE, INTERRUPTED

Silvestri may have a kindred spirit in New Zealand.

Footage shot in an Otago University lecture theatre and uploaded to Facebook in September last year appears to show a student wandering to the front of the lecture theatre to plug his phone in.

The lecturer is lost for words as the class finds the whole thing hilarious. Naturally, the incident was filmed, suggesting this was not an entirely spontaneous act.

The student, Josh Mo, later posted on the page: "1% battery. Had no choice, important conversation with my mum".

Head to our Facebook page for more from Stuff Entertainment

stories.alt_headline: Pere's Hilton: a hotel for cats and dogs
stories.alt_intro: Those who take advantage of luxurious hotel services while they're on holiday will soon be able to give their pets the same royal treatment.
stories.body:
Those who take advantage of room service, poolside lounging and a gourmet menu on holiday will soon be able to give their pets the same royal treatment.

A Hamilton woman has revealed her plans for the country's first luxury pet hotel, which she said will offer state of the art accommodation for cats and dogs as their owners go away on holiday.

Nicola Pere has owned and operated Metro Paws doggy daycare in Frankton for two years, and hopes to have her next venture, Metro Paws 'n' Claws Luxury Pet Hotel, up and running by March 2016. 

Pere's Hilton, of sorts, will include air conditioned suites, a daycare environment during daylight hours and a gourmet menu with raw food options. And that's just the beginning, Pere said.

"We are looking at adding in a pool, that's stage two ... and hydrotherapy and grooming."

The venture isn't cheap, but based on research on a successful pet hotel in Los Angeles and feedback from some of her 700 customers, Pere is certain there's a need for the service.

"To set something like this up is in the vicinity of $600,000," Pere said.

"The feedback from our customers here is they would love a facility like that."

So important is their pet's happiness, that some dog owners are going without daily luxuries so their pets get high-end treatment. 

Pere said one client admitted to giving up her cleaner so her pooch could go to doggy daycare twice a week.

"It's a billion dollar industry, the pet industry in New Zealand. The food, the accessories, the toys, there's no expense spared on their dogs."

READ MORE
* How New Zealanders pamper their pets
* Groom service is standard at Singapore pet hotel
* New Zealand legally recognises animals as 'sentient beings'
 

Pere said some customers who used her daycare services, a "high proportion" of which were gay and lesbian couples, made similar sacrifices for their pets that they'd make for children.

"We have families of two and three [dogs] that come five days a week here and spend hundreds of dollars a week on their pets, but it's their children. You'd spend that on your children."

The Hamilton site is roughly 4000 square metres and is beside Hamilton Airport, Pere said, as well as nearby Mystery Creek which hosts the annual national agricultural Fieldays.

Once the "test model" is up and going, Pere said she wants to roll out 12-14 luxury pet hotels across the country. She's currently in the final stages of resource consent with Waipa District Council, she said.

Pere said many of her clients were not comfortable leaving their dogs in a kennel "to sleep outside in a pen," but some did employ pet sitters to visit their home so pets could enjoy normal creature comforts.

Pet sitter Kyra Lindsey charges a small fee for in-house visits to pet owners' homes while they're away on holiday.

Lindsey, who works as a children's counsellor, said she does the basic chores such as feeding and walking, and will meet with owners before they go away. She said pet owners are becoming more aware of the well being of their furry family member.

"People are doing raw food diets for their animals because they notice a difference in their fur.

"I think a lot of animals give a lot of healing for people and people are going to judge if they don't understand that. At the end of the day, if that animal has a really strong place in that person's life they want to spend lots of money on it and it's their money, then that's their choice."

In 2014, a luxury pet hotel was unveiled in Singapore, featuring air-conditioned suites, spa services and a limousine shuttle service.

Owners can also order grooming and trimming services, a "pawdicure", mud masks, micro-bubble baths, fur dyeing and aromatherapy massages. 

Tariff:

$35/night for a small dog

$39-$45/night for medium-large dogs

Family rates available (more than one dog)

stories.alt_intro: If you find him a lady, he'll pay up: "I think a lot about how markets can make things more efficient."
stories.body:
A lovelorn 29-year-old in Birmingham, Alabama, is crowdsourcing his soulmate search, and there are some things he wants you to know...

He works 12 hours a day. He plays cornhole shirtless. He wants a girl who "knows the difference between 'Astronomy' and 'Astrology.'" And in case any of this sounds dubious, he has photos to prove that he's neither a Nigerian prince nor two midgets in a trenchcoat.

Meet Ren Lu You, the Harvard Business School graduate behind dateren.com.

Ren playing cornhole, shirtless. Photo: DateRen.com 

The site, launched last week by the McLean, Virginia, native, offers US$10,000 (NZ$14,820) to anyone who introduces him to a woman that he dates for more than six months. You has already received thousands of responses — half of them from women submitting themselves.

His admirers hail from IP addresses as distant as Singapore and Jakarta, Indonesia. While some might consider this a red flag for scams, You has judged these overseas propositions to be "sincere." He even received an earnest email from someone offering to sift through his submissions as an unpaid intern.

Prior to this windfall, You had tried a slew of dating methods, from getting set up by friends to the Tinder app. After going through a "mixed bag" of several dozen dates, he came away unsatisfied.

"I was an econ major in college and I work in finance now," You says, "so I think a lot about how markets can make things more efficient."

He's outdoorsy to boot. Photo: DateRen.com

This new plan may have backfired a little. Two nights ago, he stayed up until 4am combing through his crowded inbox. You had initially planned to respond to all the submissions, a feat that now appears to be impossible.

'HE CLEARLY HAS NO SHAME' 

Despite the flood of prospective girlfriends, professional matchmakers are sceptical of the venture. D.C. matchmaker Michelle Jacoby cautions that because he's asking strangers to play Cupid, they may not have his best interests at heart in the way that a friend would.

Still, she applauds You for being proactive about finding The One, even if it means that "he may go broke on dinner dates."

Maria Avgitidis, founder of the New York City-based Agape Match, says the monetary reward and public nature of You's campaign make him susceptible to fraud. After all, what's to stop two friends from "pulling a Bonnie and Clyde" and splitting the cash after a six-month ruse?

Pointing out that the bachelor has already done interviews with ABC's Good Morning America and People magazine, she adds, "He clearly has no shame." Single women who might otherwise have found You attractive are likely to be turned off by the media attention that they would receive for dating him. "This guy sounds like an incredible narcissist," Avgitidis says. "Our clients would never do anything like this."

Blue steel. Photo: DateRen.com

But You insists that his aims are pure. "I just want to find somebody who is really great, to date them and be their boyfriend," he says. "Who knows where it might go from there?"

Though he has been contacted by a TLC representative about potentially starring in a reality show, You has no interest in becoming "an F-List celebrity, like Pauly D or whatever-his-name-is on Jersey Shore." He already has his hands full as an associate at a private equity firm — "a real job."

At the very least, You's dating profile now has more hits than it ever would have gotten on OkCupid, and he has yet to pay anyone a cent.

- For more from Life & Style direct to your newsfeed, like us on Facebook.

stories.alt_intro: An heir flashes her bum, models fail to make outfits work and Rita Ora pulls off a tricky look.
stories.body:
In this week's round-up of the best and worst in celebrity red carpets, an heir flashes her bum and models fail to make outfits work while Naomi Watts and Jena Malone look crisp and chic. 

READ MORE
*Best & worst dressed: July 3
*How much celebs are paid to wear dresses
*Best & worst dressed of the year 2014
*Best & worst dressed of the year 2013

In this weekly fashion fest we only bring you the horrors and the hits from the red carpets and only cover events where celebrities know they'll be snapped and critiqued for their fashion (so no Britney leaving Maccas in her trackies.) Why? Well because all humans - even celebs - should be allowed to look rubbish while packing a Quarter Pounder (testify!).

- Head to our Facebook page for more from Stuff Life & Style

images.caption: THE BEST: Describe this Miu Miu dress with its lime-green-racer-cut-lampshade of a top half, and it doesn't sound good. But chuck it on Jena Malone, throw in a beautiful silken green clutch and a perfect blonde bob, and we have an absolute winner on our hands. Super crisp, super chic and just different enough.

THE GOOD: Dianna Agron looks beautiful in burgundy. Her hair and make up is on point too: there's nothing like some fake fruit in the background to really offset a beauty look. The very-wearable day-to-night silk halter dress is by Tory Burch, while the metallic clutch is Rodo. As I sit here in my freezing Wellington home (wearing a jacket while also under a duvet), I like to imagine myself strolling around Paris in the summertime sipping a green juice in this dress, while also sporting big-hair-don't-care, aviators and gold Grecian sandals, my oft-used yoga mat sticking out of my giant designer tote #lifegoals. PS: I have no idea where my yoga mat is. Maybe hanging with my weighted skipping rope in the back of some cupboard somewhere. Now pass me my wine.

THE GOOD: No, this isn't a highly-produced and photoshopped fashion editorial shoot, these photos were taken while Chinese actress Ni Ni sauntered into the Dior show at Paris Fashion Week. The classic, will-never-go-out-of-style Dior dress could be mumsy on some, but not on Ni Ni when paired with haute pink heels and some seriously directional sunnies: so chic it hurts. PS: You may recognise her from The Flowers of War, that movie with Christian Bale that came out circa five or so years ago. PPS: She's really selling upper ear rim earrings to me. More than most.

THE GOOD: Ladies and gents, pin this one straight to your 'chic-but-not-overcooked city wedding' Pinterest board, because it's a beaut'. Naomi Watts looks flirty, frivolous but not an ounce contrived or trying-too-hard in this white lace Armani dress. In this context, I'm even feeling the let's-be-honest-a-bit-boring beige shoes. PS: That bob is also going on my 'hairspiration: hairdos I want but would never have the energy to maintain (hello platinum blonde roots!)' Pinterest board.

THE GOOD: Speaking of great hair ... here's Black Sails star Clara Paget in Burberry proving that sometimes a simple column dress with a touch of ruching is all you need to make a statement. (Oh, that and a good old lashing of 'she's-got-air-in-her-hair' volume in your perfectly-dyed strawberry blonde locks.)

THE WILD CARD: Every iota of my being knows that those red boots are a no, but somehow Rita Ora in all her glory is actually making me like this. The Versace ensemble is very Austin Powers-meets-Pretty Woman, but Ms Ora looks amazing (hells, if I ever stumbled upon a picture in which I looked this fantastic, I'd blow it up, frame it, and put it in my living room. I remember once seeing a Cribs in which Carmen Electra and Dave Navarro had a giant piece of artwork of them nude and intimate plastered across their dining room wall. You know, because we all want some soft porn featuring our dinner hosts hoveirng over us mid-entree. I almost admire their oblivion.)

THE BAD: When does one's swinging-60s, shower curtain-inspired Versace dress traverse adorkable territory and become all-out trashy? When it exposes the entire bottom half of your ass. Delete the mesh bits and keep the giant eyelets, and I think we'd have a winner on our hands with Nicky Hilton's look. Currently, however, this Swiss cheese-meets-R2D2 adult sci-fi film convention costume is a no.

THE BAD: Rosie Huntington-Whiteley is a goddess that makes all material and fabric look flattering, but still, let's be real, this Versace dress looks like a piece of negligee that's been ravaged by some kind of tornado (during which a collection of dirty leaves wrapped around RHW's neck). It's one thing for something to look a bit like lingerie, it's quite another for a designer to craft an evening gown that looks like a nightie that's been compromised.

THE BAD: The pale-making hair, gothic lips and the fact her dress looks like a veiny shower curtain means Poppy Delevingne is giving off major zombie vibes here. (A stylish undead, however.) PS: Yes, that is a pair of breasts embroidered into the bottom of her Christopher Kane skirt. Oh yep, and there's another set of knockers right below her bra line. Because, you know, paisley is so 2014, floral so 2013 ... it's now all about nipple sequins.

THE BAD: Oh Karl, what have you done to the resplendent Lilly Collins?! Perhaps his perma-sunglasses actually distort his vision, because the Chanel designer seems to have at some point decided a harem jumpsuit made out of dirty doily lace was a good idea. Nicht. Nein. Jog on.

THE BAD: If I was to write a semi-porny Mills & Boon-style-novel about woodland creatures and fairies and the like, this exact Versace dress would be what my heroine would wear in the erotic novel's cover illustration. Karlie Kloss is giving it her all, and of course she looks fabulous, but that doesn't change the fact that we can see her entire side buttock. (Actually, maybe I should make a career change and push out some woodland erotica? Surely there's money in that. "The squirrel dashed hurriedly down Pixie's leg. She sighed. The furry touch reminding her of her one night of passion with Artemis the centaur.")

THE BAD: Anna Dello Russo channels a fast food employee who's lost a bunch of weight but hasn't updated his uniform yet. But, the thing is, those aren't cheap polyester work pants. Oh no. The entire outfit is by Gucci, ergo would cost thousands. Also, I usually dig Anna's irreverence, but an animal fur 'trinket' being four times the size of the handbag it's hanging off of is a straight-up fail.
Rita and Rosie went for bold looks this week, with mixed results.

stories.alt_headline: Which colour is closer to the shoe?
stories.alt_intro: Move over #TheDress, the internet is now losing it over this nail polish and shoe mind-bender.
stories.body:
If you hated #TheDress, then you might want to stop reading right now.

There's a new illusion sweeping Twitter that compares two different nail polishes to a pair of high heeled pinkish-purple shoes.

People simply can't figure out which polish is closer in colour to the shoes. 

At the time of this post, the original tweet has over 6,300 favourites and has been retweeted 5,000 times.

Publications such as BuzzFeed, Mashable, and Cosmopolitan have all picked it up, too. They're calling it #TheShoe.

People can't agree which colour of nail polish best matches the shoes. Is it the right?

But to solve this once and for all, we turned to Photoshop where you can see where the colours of the shoe and the nail polishes fall on the spectrum.

Though at first I was in the right polish camp, now I have to admit that the left polish would be the better match since the shoe falls more on the purple scale than the pink colour scale.

To prove my point, here's what the right nail polish colour looks like side-by-side with the lightest and the darkest colours on the shoe:And here's what the left nail polish looks like next to the brightest and darkest colours in the shoe. As you can see, these are a much closer match than the bright pink polish:

So if anyone asks, it's the left polish.

- For more from Life & Style, head over and like our Facebook page.

stories.alt_intro: From long distance love to a dreamy wedding in New York, these Kiwi ladies' wedding was picture perfect.
stories.body:
Introducing Kirsten Dinnan, 33, and Hannah Dinnan (nee Smith), 32.

The retail manager and research associate from Palmerston North had many happy years together (although much of that separated by the Cook Strait) before they tied the knot in Central Park.

From Hannah's beautiful ivory lace dress to Kirsten's superhero statement socks, this beautiful day was equal parts romanticism and whimsy - just perfect. 

We'll let Hannah tell you all about it... 

How did you meet? Kirsten and I were part of a group who became friends after contributing to an online forum. We eventually exchanged phone numbers and I soon fell for Kirsten's quick sense of humour and clever mind. Kirsten was living in Dunedin and I was in Palmerston North, so it was a few months before we actually met when a friend sneakily organised to get Kirsten up to Palmerston North for my birthday. She was delivered to my door covered in wrapping paper and topped off with a bow!

Tell us about the proposal: Kirsten bought a ring six months after we became a couple and proposed the day after our one year anniversary. We were young and doing long distance, so wedding plans never went beyond daydreams. Over the next eight happy years there were three years of long distance, a "re-proposal" with a second gorgeous engagement ring and a surprise helicopter flight, a first home, a serious car accident and a third (and final) sparkly engagement ring.

I have always loved weddings, but found planning ours very overwhelming. We had previously joked about eloping but after Kirsten's accident we decided we didn't want to wait anymore and started planning our New York wedding.

Unfortunately our parents couldn't come, but were all very supportive and understanding. However, two of our best friends (Krystal and Sarah) joined us on our adventure which was very special! (Note from my wife Kirsten: "Avoid long engagements if you are marrying a girl who loves sparkly things").

Location of wedding: Shakespeare's Garden; a small, beautiful, secluded garden in Central Park, New York City. It was spring, so the garden was full of colour and we got married under a magnificent magnolia tree in bloom while surrounded by tulips and spring flowers.

Describe your wedding day: Our day started in a helicopter flying around the Statue of Liberty and up the Hudson River. It is such an amazing way to experience New York City.

We then headed back to our hotel to meet our lovely hair and make-up artist (Cari Duprey) and her fabulous sidekick. We planned it so Kirsten and Krystal would get ready first and then head up to the hotel's rooftop bar. This meant that Kirsten wouldn't see me all made-up and dressed until I met her on the rooftop for our "first look" photos. After a tequila shot to steady our nerves we walked to the subway station to catch our train to Central Park. It was rush hour so the subway was packed! 

We met our very sweet celebrant (Judie Guild) at the gardens and after laughter, tears, lovely dinosaurs and zombies we were legally wife and wife.

After the ceremony we had photos taken in Central Park before we said goodbye to Amber and hailed a famous yellow cab to take us to dinner. We had dinner at Candle 79, a highly recommended vegan restaurant. I'm the only vegetarian in the group, but the meat eaters all agreed the food was incredible! The restaurant staff were delightful and made such a fuss of us. 

With full bellies we headed to the Empire State Building to see New York City sparkle at night. It was the perfect way to end our magical day. 

The dress: I struggled to find a dress in NZ, so after much agonising I decided to stop stressing about it and find something in New York. Thankfully we discovered BHLDN and I found a gorgeous dress (Celestina). I also found a stunning coat at Macy's to protect me from the springtime weather.

My spunky bride wore a shirt that matched her baby blues and one Superman sock and one Batman sock as she couldn't decide on her favourite superhero (she also wore Wonder Woman underwear!). 

The flowers: Tulips were in bloom everywhere in New York, so it seemed fitting to have a bunch as my wedding bouquet. We got them from a small shop in Penn Station on the way back from the helicopter terminal and I tied them with a ribbon from the Tiffany's box that contained my "something new" necklace. My bouquet later became our table centrepiece at dinner. 

Highlight of the wedding: It's so hard to pick just one! Kirsten's face when she saw me as her bride for the first time. Saying our vows and declaring "till death or zombies do us part" under a gorgeous magnolia tree. Our first dance (a spontaneous moment dancing to a Beatles song performed by some musicians having a jam session in Central Park). Watching a squirrel unsuccessfully try to bury his nuts in some muddy water behind one of the rocks where we were having our photos taken.

Oh, and the laughter (and tears) at dinner while we read letters of congratulations and marriage advice collected from our friends and family before we left New Zealand.

Was there any drama? Thankfully we had no major dramas beyond our helicopter flight being delayed by an hour which meant we were a bit rushed to make it back to our hotel in time for hair and make-up. Oh, that and wedding shoe blisters! 

The honeymoon: All four of us adventured our way from New York to Washington DC, Las Vegas, San Francisco, Anaheim and finally to Los Angeles. We ate delicious food, saw the sun set over the Grand Canyon, got to be big kids at Disneyland, froze at a Yankees game, explored art galleries and museums, were amazed by Broadway and Cirque du Soleil performances, lost money in Vegas, squealed over squirrels, shopped as much as our baggage limit would allow and made memories for a lifetime.

Your photographer and favourite photo? We were lucky enough to stumble across our amazing photographer Amber Marlow while researching New York elopements.

Her style was exactly what we were after, and she was as wonderful in real life as she was when we were trying to organise everything from afar.

My dear wife will say every photo is her favourite, but in particular we love the photos that show the New York skyline and also the one of Kirsten giving me a piggyback off the rocks (I was having difficulty in my heels).

I think Amber captured our happiness and delight with each other perfectly.
